thread.title: US state secretary nominee holds off judgment on Duterte
thread.title_full: US state secretary nominee holds off judgment on Duterte

title: US state secretary nominee holds off judgment on Duterte
text:
US state secretary nominee holds off judgment on Duterte By Jose Katigbak, STAR Washington bureau (The Philippine Star)   12:00am Tillerson 
WASHINGTON – US secretary of state nominee Rex Tillerson backed off from publicly denouncing President Duterte for the mounting anti-drug killings in the Philippines until he had all the facts in hand. 
At his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday, Tillerson, a former CEO of ExxonMobile, said if facts support allegations of extrajudicial killings “then I don’t think any of us would accept that as a proper way to deal with offenders,” no matter how egregious their crimes might be. 
Republican Sen. Marco Rubio in his questioning of Tillerson said since Duterte took office on June 30, police and vigilantes have killed about 6,200 people in the anti-drug war. 
Rubio said Duterte himself bragged that when he was mayor of Davao he personally killed suspected criminals to encourage police to do the same, a claim Duterte’s aides have sought to play down as an exaggeration. 
When Rubio pressed Tillerson to state his view as to whether this was the right way to conduct an anti-drug campaign, the nominee pointed out that the US and the Philippines have a long-standing friendship. 
“I think it is important that we keep that in perspective, that long-standing friendship. We need to be sure they stay an ally,” Tillerson said. Headlines ( Article MRec ), pagematch: 1, sectionmatch: 1 
On China, Tillerson said Beijing’s declaration of an air defense identification zone in the East China Sea over Japanese-controlled Senkaku Islands and its island building in the South China Sea were illegal actions. 
“They are taking territory or control or declaring control of territories that are not rightfully China’s,” he said. 
He said China’s building of artificial islands and putting military assets to those islands was akin to Russia’s taking of Crimea. 
“We have to send China a clear signal – that the island building stops and second, your access to those islands is also not allowed,” Tillerson said. Headlines ( Article MRec ), pagematch: 1, sectionmatch: 1
